hero.title: Glossary
hero.subtitle: Key terms you'll encounter in Ashtanga Yoga

terms.definition: Means "eight limbs" in Sanskrit. Refers to the eight-limbed path of yoga outlined by Patanjali, and also to the specific style of yoga taught by K. Pattabhi Jois.
A city in Karnataka, India, where Ashtanga Yoga was developed. Also refers to the self-paced teaching style where students practice individually while the teacher provides one-on-one guidance.
A yoga school or practice space. Literally means "home" or "hall" in Sanskrit.
The synchronisation of breath and movement. Each movement in Ashtanga has a specific breath count.

The numbered sequence of breaths and movements for each posture. In Ashtanga, each pose has a specific count (in Sanskrit) that coordinates inhales and exhales with movements. Learning the correct vinyasa count helps practitioners maintain the rhythm and flow of the practice.
The breathing technique used throughout Ashtanga practice. Created by slightly constricting the throat, producing a soft, ocean-like sound.
Energy locks in the body. The three main bandhas are Mula Bandha (root lock), Uddiyana Bandha (abdominal lock), and Jalandhara Bandha (throat lock).
Gazing point. Each asana has a specific drishti to help focus the mind and direct energy.

Ethical restraints. The first limb of Ashtanga yoga. Five principles for how we relate to the world: non-violence (ahimsa), truthfulness (satya), non-stealing (asteya), moderation (brahmacharya), and non-possessiveness (aparigraha).

Personal observances. The second limb of Ashtanga yoga. Five practices for self-discipline: cleanliness (saucha), contentment (santosha), discipline (tapas), self-study (svadhyaya), and surrender to a higher power (ishvara pranidhana).
Physical posture. The third limb of Ashtanga yoga. In common usage, refers to the poses practiced in yoga.
Sun Salutation. The opening sequence of Ashtanga practice. There are two versions: A and B.
Yoga Chikitsa (योग चिकित्सा), meaning "yoga therapy." The first series of Ashtanga, focused on detoxifying and aligning the body.
A class where all students move together following the teacher's count, as opposed to Mysore style where each student moves at their own pace.
The lineage or succession of teachers passing knowledge from guru to student. An important concept in traditional yoga.

Corpse pose. You might hear of it as the final resting pose at the end of practice, however, in Ashtanga we don't say Savasana, we only say rest. This is the where the body integrates the benefits of the practice.
Prana means breath in Sanskrit. Pranayama is the breath control practice. The fourth limb of Ashtanga yoga. Traditionally taught after proficiency in asana.
Withdrawal of the senses. The fifth limb of Ashtanga yoga. The practice of turning attention inward by withdrawing from external distractions, preparing the mind for concentration.
Concentration. The sixth limb of Ashtanga yoga. The practice of focusing the mind on a single point. In Ashtanga, cultivated through drishti and awareness of breath.
Meditation. The seventh limb of Ashtanga yoga. An unbroken flow of awareness where the mind becomes still and absorbed.
Absorption or enlightenment. The eighth and final limb of Ashtanga yoga. A state of complete union and the ultimate goal of yoga practice.
Full and new moon days when Ashtanga practitioners traditionally rest from practice.
The ancient Indian language in which yoga texts are written. Pose names and counting in Ashtanga are traditionally done in Sanskrit.
Sacred sound or phrase. Ashtanga practice traditionally begins and ends with specific chanted mantras.
Teacher or spiritual guide. Literally means "dispeller of darkness."
Community of practitioners. In yoga, refers to the supportive community of fellow students and teachers who share the practice.

Literally means "being in the company of truth." A gathering of practitioners to listen to teachings, discuss spiritual matters, or simply be in the presence of a teacher or like-minded community. From 'sat' (truth) and 'sanga' (company).
Spiritual practice or discipline. Your daily yoga practice is your sadhana—a dedicated effort toward self-realisation.
Action, and the consequences of action. In yoga philosophy, refers to the principle that every action has effects that shape our future experiences.

Equal standing. The foundational standing posture where you stand at attention with feet together, arms by your sides, and weight evenly distributed. The starting and returning point for many sequences.
The Ashtanga opening prayer chanted at the beginning of practice, honouring the lineage of teachers. It begins with 'Vande Gurunam' and is traditionally done in call-and-response with the teacher.
The prayer chanted at the end of Ashtanga practice, offering the benefits of the practice to all beings. It begins with 'Svasthi Praja Bhyaha' and wishes peace and wellbeing to all.

Literally means "thread" in Sanskrit. Refers to a concise teaching or aphorism. The Yoga Sutras of Patanjali are the foundational text of yoga philosophy, containing 196 sutras on the theory and practice of yoga.

K. Pattabhi Jois Ashtanga Yoga Institute. The original institute in Mysore, India, founded by Sri K. Pattabhi Jois where Ashtanga Yoga has been taught since 1948. It was led by his grandson R. Sharath Jois until his passing in 2024, and remains the main source of the Ashtanga lineage.

Sharath Yoga Centre. The main Ashtanga Yoga shala in Mysore, India, founded by R. Sharath Jois. Students from around the world travel to Mysore to study at SYC and deepen their practice in the tradition of the Ashtanga lineage.

A teacher who has been granted permission by the KPJAYI/SYC lineage to teach Ashtanga Yoga. Authorisation is given after years of dedicated practice and study in Mysore. There are different levels: Authorised Level 1 (can teach Primary Series) and Authorised Level 2 (can teach up to Intermediate Series). This differs from Certified teachers, who have received the highest level of recognition and can teach all series.

Sri Krishna Pattabhi Jois (1915–2009), known as Guruji, was the founder of Ashtanga Yoga as it is practiced today. He learned from his teacher T. Krishnamacharya and dedicated his life to teaching in Mysore, India. He established KPJAYI and trained thousands of students from around the world, spreading Ashtanga globally.

R. Sharath Jois (1971–2024) was the lineage holder of Ashtanga Yoga and grandson of K. Pattabhi Jois. He began practicing at age 7 and taught since 1994. He founded Sharath Yoga Centre (SYC) in Mysore, continuing the tradition and authorising teachers worldwide until his passing.

Tirumalai Krishnamacharya (1888–1989), often called the "father of modern yoga." He was the teacher of K. Pattabhi Jois, B.K.S. Iyengar, and Indra Devi, among others. His teachings form the foundation of most modern yoga styles practiced today.

The highest level of recognition granted by the KPJAYI/SYC lineage to teach Ashtanga Yoga. Certified teachers have demonstrated mastery of the practice and can teach all series. This is a step above Authorised teachers, who are limited to teaching Primary or Intermediate Series depending on their level.

Nadi Shodhana, meaning "nerve cleansing." The second series of Ashtanga, focused on purifying the nervous system. It includes deeper backbends, hip openers, and arm balances. Students typically begin this series after completing Primary Series.

Sthira Bhaga, meaning "divine stability." The third and most challenging series of Ashtanga (actually divided into four sub-series: Advanced A, B, C, and D). It integrates strength, flexibility, and grace at the highest level.
The three places of attention in Ashtanga practice: breathing system (pranayama), posture (asana), and gazing point (drishti). These three elements work together to create a moving meditation.

The ancient sage who compiled the Yoga Sutras, the foundational text of yoga philosophy. His work outlines the eight-limbed path (Ashtanga) and provides guidance on the practice and purpose of yoga. Little is known about his life, with estimates placing him between 500 BCE and 400 CE.

A pose that acts as a checkpoint in the Ashtanga sequence. Your teacher will only give you the next pose once you've developed the strength, flexibility, or understanding needed to practice it safely. Common gatekeepers include Marichyasana D and Supta Kurmasana in the Primary Series.

Alternate nostril breathing, a pranayama technique that purifies the energy channels (nadis). Sharath Jois introduced this practice into the finishing sequence before Uth Pluthi. It balances the left and right sides of the body and calms the nervous system.
